        'Who flips the tiles on ''Wheel of Fortune''?'???
Answer:
The Wheel of Fortune is a popular television game show that has been entertaining audiences for over 50 years. The show features a large rotating wheel with letters, numbers, and special spaces on it. Contestants spin the wheel in an attempt to win prizes by landing on specific spaces. One of the most iconic aspects of the show is the 'tiles' that are flipped over to reveal the letters on the wheel.

The tiles on Wheel of Fortune are typically made of a durable plastic material and are designed to be easily flipped over. They come in a variety of colors, including red, green, blue, yellow, and orange. The tiles are also marked with numbers and special spaces, such as 'Bankrupt,' 'Go To Jail,' and 'Free Spin.'

The process of flipping the tiles on Wheel of Fortune is relatively simple. When a contestant lands on a space that requires them to flip a tile, they will typically reach out and grab the tile with their hand. They will then lift the tile up and flip it over, revealing the letter or number underneath. The tiles are designed to be easy to flip, so contestants can quickly and easily reveal the information they need.

In addition to being used on Wheel of Fortune, tiles are also commonly used in other games and activities. For example, they may be used in board games, card games, or even in outdoor sports like soccer or basketball. Tiles are a versatile and convenient way to add an element of chance or strategy to any game or activity.

Overall, the tiles on Wheel of Fortune play an important role in the show's gameplay and are a beloved part of its iconic design. They are simple to flip, durable, and easy to read, making them the perfect choice for revealing information on the wheel.

        Rap mogul Suge Knight to surrender in connection with deadly hit-and-run, lawyer says
Jan. 29, 2015: A Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department investigator photographs the scene of an accident at a parking lot in Compton, Calif. A lawyer for Marion 'Suge' Knight, a Death Row Records founder, says Knight was driving a car involved in an accident. (AP Photo/Damian Dovarganes)

An attorney for rap mogul Marion 'Suge' Knight says he is working with Los Angeles County sheriff's officials to have Knight surrender for questioning in connection with a deadly hit-and-run Thursday.

MyFoxLA, citing attorney James Blatt, reported that Knight was at the wheel of a car that struck two men shortly before 3 p.m. local time in Compton. One of the men died, while the other was taken to a hospital. The injured man's condition was not immediately available and neither man's name was released.

The Los Angeles Times reported that the tragedy stemmed from an altercation that occurred on the set of the forthcoming film 'Straight Outta Compton,' a biopic about the rap group NWA. Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department Capt. John Corina said that the two men Knight argued with went to a nearby restaurant about 20 minutes after the confrontation

Corina alleged Knight followed the men there in a red truck and ran them over in the parking lot. Witnesses told the paper the truck hit the men, then backed over them before fleeing the scene. The incident is being investigated as a homicide.

Blatt claimed to the Associated Press that Knight was trying to escape from a pair of attackers and said he was confident that his client will be cleared of wrongdoing.

Knight co-founded Death Row Records with Dr. Dre in 1991 and built it into the first successful mainstream rap label behind acts like NWA, Snoop Dogg, and Tupac Shakur. Knight was at the wheel of the BMW Shakur was riding in when he was shot and killed following a boxing match in Las Vegas.

Knight has had repeated brushes with the law. In 1997, he was sentenced to nine years in prison for violating the terms of his probation in an earlier assault case. He was released in 2001. In 2008, he was arrested in Las Vegas on suspicion of drug possession and aggravated assault and pleaded guilty to a charge of misdemeanor battery the following year. He is currently waiting trial alongside comedian Katt Williams on charges of second degree robbery in connection with the theft of a photographer's camera.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.

Click for more from MyFoxLA.com.

Click for more from The Los Angeles Times.
What is a short summary of the above article?
Answer: Rap mogul Marion 'Suge' Knight, who co-founded Death Row Records with Dr. Dre in 1991 and built it into the first successful mainstream rap label behind acts like NWA, Snoop Dogg, and Tupac Shakur, is being investigated for a deadly hit-and-run that occurred on the set of the forthcoming film 'Straight Outta Compton,' a biopic about the rap group NWA. Knight was at the wheel of a car that struck two men shortly before 3 p.m. local time in Compton, killing one and injuring the other. The incident is being investigated as a homicide. Knight's attorney James Blatt claims his client was trying to escape from a pair of attackers and says he will be cleared of wrongdoing. Knight has had repeated brushes with the law, including serving nine years in prison for violating the terms of his probation in an earlier assault case. He is currently waiting trial alongside comedian Katt Williams on charges of second degree robbery in connection with the theft of a photographer's camera.

question:Corky was a brave young man and he dreamed of becoming the best fighter in the world. To become stronger and get better fighting skills, he went to many schools. One day, he went to the best school in the world. Before entering the gate, he was made to hand in all his weapons  . 'You won't need those any more. Here you'll get better ones,' said the guard. Corky handed his weapons to him. A serious old teacher took Corky to his room. Before he left, he said to Corky, 'In a hundred days the training will start.' A hundred days! At first Corky thought that was a joke, but he soon realized the old teacher had been serious. Corky felt nervous during the first days and he tried many ways to try to get the teacher to start the training. However, it didn't work. Corky could hardly believe it, but he really understood that the teacher was right. Finally, the lesson began. 'Now it's time to learn how to win every fight,' said the old teacher. That sounded good to Corky until he found himself tied hand and foot. Many villagers tried to hit him because they were told that Corky was a dangerous man. The same thing was repeated for days, and Corky knew he had to do something. He realized that the only way would be to deal with the villagers' anger  . Answer: C) Because he wanted Corky to be patient.

        I can use this background: The trade-off theory of capital structure is the idea that a company chooses how much debt finance and how much equity finance to use by balancing the costs and benefits. The classical version of the hypothesis goes back to Kraus and Litzenberger[1] who considered a balance between the dead-weight costs of bankruptcy and the tax saving benefits of debt. Often agency costs are also included in the balance. This theory is often set up as a competitor theory to the pecking order theory of capital structure. A review of the literature is provided by Frank and Goyal.[2]  An important purpose of the theory is to explain the fact that corporations usually are financed partly with debt and partly with equity. It states that there is an advantage to financing with debt, the tax benefits of debt and there is a cost of financing with debt, the costs of financial distress including bankruptcy costs of debt and non-bankruptcy costs (e.g. staff leaving, suppliers demanding disadvantageous payment terms, bondholder/stockholder infighting, etc.). The marginal benefit of further increases in debt declines as debt increases, while the marginal cost increases, so that a firm that is optimizing its overall value will focus on this trade-off when choosing how much debt and equity to use for financing.  Now, I have a new situation: Bob is a financial analyst. He used to work for company A. Bob noticed that company A is mostly financed by debt. Recently, he changed job and now working as a financial analyst for another company, company B. Company B has completely different culture than company A. Company B is mostly financed by equity.  Answer this question please: Would company B have or not have tax benefits of debt?
Answer: To answer this question, we need to understand the concept of tax benefits of debt. The tax benefits of debt refer to the fact that interest paid on debt is generally tax-deductible, while dividends paid on equity are not. This means that a company that finances with debt will have lower after-tax costs than a company that finances with equity.  However, this only applies if the company has a positive tax rate. If the company has a negative tax rate (i.e. it is in a loss position), then the interest paid on debt will not be tax-deductible and the dividends paid on equity will not be taxed. In this case, financing with equity may actually be more advantageous than financing with debt.  So, to answer the question, company B would have or not have tax benefits of debt, it depends on the company's tax rate. If the company has a positive tax rate, then financing with debt will provide tax benefits, but if the company has a negative tax rate, then financing with equity may be more advantageous.

        Article:The Ariane 6 will succeed the Ariane 5, which, although highly successful, is now facing stiff competition on price.
The politicians believe industry will find the new vehicle cheaper to construct and to operate.
European Space Agency member states authorised the project at a special council meeting in Luxembourg, where they also agreed funding for the space station and a rover to go to Mars.
All up, the Esa nations came forward with 5.924bn euros in contributions to cover a number of programmes over the next few years.
'I think I can summarise this ministerial council by saying it is a success; I'd even go so far as to say that it is a great success,' said agency director-general Jean-Jacques Dordain.
The Ariane 5 has been operating since the mid-1990s and has come to dominate the market for putting up big commercial satellites.
But its position is now under threat from competitor services offering lower prices.  The fear is that the 5's position will be eroded inexorably in the latter half of this decade.
The Ariane 6 concept is seen as the riposte. This vehicle would employ more modern methods of production and a streamlined assembly to try to reduce unit costs.
Moreover, because the rocket's modular design can be tailored to a wide range of satellite and mission types, it should gain further economies from frequent use.
Ministers committed 4bn euros to cover not only the 6's development but also an upgrade to Esa's small Italian-built Vega rocket. In future, these two vehicles will actually share some propulsion elements.
'They will be a true family with the same DNA,' said Mr Dordain.
After months - and a final day - of hard bargaining, Europe's two big space powers, France and Germany, came together to push Ariane 6 forward.
France always intended to put up most of the money, but it needed German support financially and programatically.
This it got by fulfilling commitments to the International Space Station, which Germany regards as central to its space endeavours.
The meeting agreed 800 million euros be spent on the ISS and related activities up to 2017 - just 20 million short of what had been asked at the start of the day.
This was achieved in part by the Italians promising to return eventually to funding levels it withdrew from a couple of years ago, and by the UK, which gave a 'one-off' payment to the ISS at the last ministerial gathering in 2012, coming up with a further, increased contribution.
The third big issue for the Luxembourg gathering concerned the ExoMars rover, which is due to be sent to the Red Planet in 2018 to search for signs of past or present life.
It is a project with a troubled history that has come within a breath of being cancelled on more than one occasion.
Its persistent woe has been a shortfall in the money needed to carry the venture through to completion. This gap is on the order of 200 million euros. Ministers could only promise 140 million euros in Luxembourg, even after the UK and Italy, the 'champions of ExoMars', upped their participation. But Mr Dordain told reporters the sum was enough for now to keep the mission on track.
'It means I can sign industrial contracts next year,' he explained.
Other programmes to be approved at the meeting included the next phase of Sentinel-6, a future satellite for the EU to measure the shape of the oceans; and 'AnySat', which is a concept for small, adaptable telecommunications spacecraft.

A summary of the above article is?
Answer: The European Space Agency (ESA) has approved the development of the Ariane 6 rocket, which will succeed the Ariane 5. The new vehicle is expected to be cheaper to construct and operate, and will compete with lower-priced services offered by competitors. The ESA nations committed 5.924 billion euros in contributions to cover a number of programs over the next few years, including the space station and a rover to go to Mars. The Ariane 6 concept is seen as a response to the threat posed by lower-priced services. The rocket's modular design will allow it to be tailored to a wide range of satellite and mission types, and will gain further economies

When a glacier moves through irregular terrain, cracks called crevasses develop in the fracture zone. Crevasses form due to differences in glacier velocity. If two rigid sections of a glacier move at different speeds and directions, shear forces cause them to break apart, opening a crevasse. Crevasses are seldom more than 46 m (150 ft) deep but in some cases can be 300 m (1,000 ft) or even deeper. Beneath this point, the plasticity of the ice is too great for cracks to form. A:
Answer: Intersecting crevasses can create isolated peaks in the ice, called seracs.

In December 2005, the two ton Reclining Figure (1969–70) – insured for £3 million – was lifted by crane from the grounds of the Henry Moore Foundation on to a lorry and has not been recovered. Two men were jailed for a year in 2012 for stealing a sculpture called Sundial (1965) and the bronze plinth of another work, also from the foundation's estate. In October 2013 Standing Figure (1950), one of four Moore pieces in Glenkiln Sculpture Park, estimated to be worth £3 million, was stolen. In 2012, the council of the London Borough of Tower Hamlets announced its plans to sell another version of Draped Seated Woman 1957–58, a 1.6-tonne bronze sculpture. Moore, a well-known socialist, had sold the sculpture at a fraction of its market value to the former London County Council on the understanding that it would be displayed in a public space and might enrich the lives of those living in a socially deprived area. Nicknamed Old Flo, it was installed on the Stifford council estate in 1962 but was vandalised and moved to the Yorkshire Sculpture Park in 1997. Tower Hamlets Council later had considered moving Draped Seated Woman to private land in Canary Wharf but instead chose to 'explore options' for a sale. In response to the announcement an open letter was published in The Guardian, signed by Mary Moore, the artist's daughter, by Sir Nicholas Serota, Director of the Tate Gallery, by filmmaker Danny Boyle, and by artists including Jeremy Deller. The letter said that the sale 'goes against the spirit of Henry Moore's original sale' of the work.
The answer is:
Answer: Old Flo refers to the Reclining Figure (1969–70) sculpture which was nicknamed by the public due to its resemblance to an old man lying down.

['d', 'h', '7059']
Answer:
In this input list A, there are 3 elements. The first element is a string 'd' which is an alphabet. The second element is another string 'h' which is also an alphabet. The third element is an integer 7059 which is a number.

        To solve the task, we need to count the number of alphabets and numbers in the list A. We can use two variables to keep track of these counts: num_count for numbers and alpha_count for alphabets.

        We start by initializing both num_count and alpha_count to 0. Then we iterate over each element in the list A using a loop. For each element, we check if it is an integer or a string. If it is an integer, we increment num_count by 1. If it is a string, we increment alpha_count by 1.

        After the loop, we compare the values of num_count and alpha_count to determine which one is greater. If num_count is greater than alpha_count, we print 'Numbers Win'. If alpha_count is greater than num_count, we print 'Alphabets Win'. If both counts are equal, we print 'Numbers and Alphabets are Tied'.

        In this case, since there is only one number in the list A (7059), num_count will be 1. Since there are two alphabets in the list A ('d' and 'h'), alpha_count will be 2. Therefore, alpha_count is greater than num_count, so we print 'Alphabets Win'.

Thoughts? Step-by-step reasoning:
Answer:
1. First, let's calculate how many pages Maya read last week: 5 books x 300 pages/book = 1500 pages.
2. This week she read twice as much, so she read 2 x 1500 pages = 3000 pages.

        Write an article based on this 'Attach the power cord. Move the dryer into its final position. Level the dryer. Turn the breakers and gas back on.'

Article:
Answer:
When it comes to installing a new dryer, there are several steps that need to be followed in order to ensure that it is properly set up and ready for use. One of the most important things to keep in mind during this process is safety. It is essential to follow all manufacturer instructions carefully and to take any necessary precautions to prevent accidents or injuries.

The first step in installing a new dryer is to attach the power cord. This will typically involve plugging the dryer into an electrical outlet using the provided power cord. It is important to make sure that the power cord is securely connected and that it is rated for the voltage and current requirements of the dryer.

Once the power cord is attached, the next step is to move the dryer into its final position. This will typically involve rolling the dryer on its wheels and maneuvering it into place. It is important to make sure that the dryer is level and that it is positioned in a safe and convenient location.

After the dryer is in its final position, the next step is to level it. This will typically involve adjusting the legs of the dryer or using shims to ensure that it is stable and secure. It is important to make sure that the dryer is properly leveled in order to prevent any issues with the dryer's performance or safety.

Once the dryer is level, the next step is to turn the breakers and gas back on. This will typically involve going to the electrical panel and turning on the circuit breaker for the dryer. It may also involve turning on the gas line to the dryer if it is a gas-powered model. It is important to make sure that all safety precautions are taken when turning on the power and gas, and to follow all manufacturer instructions carefully.

Finally, once everything is set up and ready, it is time to test out the new dryer. This will typically involve loading some clothes into the dryer and running a cycle to make sure that it is working properly. It is important to make sure that the dryer is properly maintained and that any issues are addressed in a timely manner in order to ensure that it continues to function safely and efficiently.

In conclusion, installing a new dryer can be a simple and straightforward process if you follow all manufacturer instructions carefully and take necessary precautions. By attaching the power cord, moving the dryer into its final position, leveling it, turning the breakers and gas back on, and testing it out, you can ensure that your new dryer is properly set up and ready for use. Remember to always prioritize safety when working with electrical and gas appliances.

For example, if an environment changes from cold to warm, organisms with thicker fur may be better adapted and more likely to survive.
        - (B) mutations: Mutations are random changes in an organism's DNA. They can occur naturally or be induced by environmental factors such as radiation or chemicals. Some mutations may be harmful, while others may be beneficial or neutral. Beneficial mutations can increase an organism's chances of survival and reproduction, leading to natural selection.
        - (C) competition: Competition for resources such as food, water, and mates is another important factor in natural selection. Organisms that are better adapted to their environment may be able to outcompete others for these resources, increasing their chances of survival and reproduction.
        - (D) relocation: Relocating to a new environment can also play a role in natural selection. If an organism is not well adapted to its new environment, it may struggle to survive and reproduce, leading to natural selection against that trait.
        - (E) Darwin: Charles Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection is the foundation of modern evolutionary biology. He proposed that species change over time through a process of natural selection, where organisms with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce.
        - (F) evolutionary development: Evolutionary development refers to the changes that occur in an organism's genetic makeup over time. These changes can be driven by natural selection, leading to the development of new species.
        - (G) root growth: Root growth is not directly related to natural selection. While roots are important for the survival and reproduction of plants, they do not play a direct role in natural selection.
        - (H) research: Research is an important tool for understanding natural selection and evolution. Scientists use various methods such as genetic analysis, comparative anatomy, and paleontology to study the mechanisms of natural selection and how they have shaped the diversity of life on Earth.

        Based on these options, we can conclude that natural selection occurs due to a combination of factors, including the environment, mutations, competition, and evolutionary development. These factors work together to create a process where organisms with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce, leading to the development of new species over time.

For example, Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) is a soil bacterium that produces a protein that can act as an insecticide, known as the Bt toxin . As a spray, the Bt toxin is in an inactive state and requires digestion by an insect to become active and have any effect. Crop plants have now been engineered to contain and express the genes for the Bt toxin, which they produce in its active form. Answer:
Answer: In case A, the Bt toxin does not need to be digested by the insects.

        In this task, you are given two strings A,B. Find the longer of the two lists, convert it to lowercase, and return all the unique alphabets used in it. The two input strings are never equal.
Q: PopIRyD, yWpIcM
A:
Answer:
1. First, we need to compare the lengths of the two strings A and B. We can use the len() function to get the length of a string.
2. Since we know that the input strings are never equal, we can assume that one of them will always be longer than the other. In this case, the length of string B is 10 while the length of string A is 9. Therefore, string B is the longer of the two strings.
3. Next, we need to convert the longer string (string B) to lowercase using the lower() function. This will ensure that all the alphabets in the string are converted to lowercase.
4. After converting string B to lowercase, we can use a set data structure to store all the unique alphabets used in it. We can iterate through each character in the string and check if it is already present in the set or not. If it is not present, we add it to the set.
5. Finally, we return the set of unique alphabets used in the longer string.

Therefore, the solution to the given task is:
```python
def find_longer_string(A,B):
    if len(A) > len(B):
        longer_string = A
    else:
        longer_string = B
    
    unique_alphabets = set()
    for char in longer_string.lower():
        if char not in unique_alphabets:
            unique_alphabets.add(char)
            
    return unique_alphabets
```

Explanation: Kyoto was once the capital of Japan and was home to the imperial court during the Heian period (794-1185). During this time, Kyoto became known as the center of Japanese culture and art, with many famous artists, poets, and scholars living in the city. The city's architecture also flourished during this period, with many temples, shrines, and other buildings being constructed.

After the Meiji Restoration in 1868, Kyoto was no longer the capital of Japan, but it remained an important cultural center. Many of the country's most famous artists, writers, and intellectuals continued to live in Kyoto, and the city's architecture also continued to evolve.

Today, Kyoto is still known for its rich cultural heritage and architectural legacy. The city is home to many temples, shrines, and other historical buildings, including the famous Fushimi Inari Shrine, which is famous for its thousands of torii gates. Kyoto is also known for its traditional tea ceremonies, geisha culture, and other cultural pursuits.

In conclusion, Kyoto has remained a center for architecture and culture throughout its history. The city's rich cultural heritage and architectural legacy continue to attract visitors from around the world, making it one of Japan's most popular tourist destinations.

There Patrick has planned to kill him.Rose mistakenly concludes that George is dead but in fact, George has killed Patrick and thrown his body into the falls.The police believe that George is the victim and when the body is retrieved and the police bring Rose to identify George's body she collapses and is admitted to a hospital.After that George comes to kill Rose in revenge but finds Polly instead and wakes to see him before he runs away. Polly tells the police who go in search of George.Rose leaves the hospital intending to return to America but finds George waiting for her. George catches her and strangles her.The Cutlers go fishing with friends in a launch on a section of the Niagara River above the Falls. When the launch is moored to allow the party to go shopping, George steals the boat with Polly on board. The police are notified and set out in pursuit. The boat runs out of gas and drifts toward the Falls. George manages to place Polly on a rock before going over the Falls to his death. Polly is rescued by helicopter.
Answer: Answer: Ray and Polly go on their honeymoon at Niagara Falls.

        Here is an article:

LOS ANGELES — With no new wide-release movies of note, it was a weekend of Thanksgiving leftovers at the box office.

The animated Disney musical “Moana” was again the No. 1 draw at North American multiplexes, collecting an estimated $28.4 million, for a two-week total of $119.9 million. “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them” (Warner Bros.) was second, taking in $18.5 million, for a three-week domestic total of $183.5 million — officially blockbuster territory, especially when adding the $424.4 million in international ticket sales.

Several art films hoping for Oscar attention played to mixed results in limited release. “Jackie” (Fox Searchlight), starring Natalie Portman as a calculating Jacqueline Kennedy, arrived in five theaters and collected a stout $275,000, according to comScore, which compiles box office data. “Miss Sloane” (EuropaCorp), starring Jessica Chastain as a political powerbroker, sold $123,036 in tickets in four theaters.

“Lion” (the Weinstein Company), an adoption drama starring Dev Patel and Nicole Kidman, managed $120,234 in seven theaters, for a two-week total of $279,382.

In its third weekend, the acclaimed drama “Manchester by the Sea” (Roadside Attractions), starring Casey Affleck and Michelle Williams, had ticket sales of $2.4 million at 156 theaters, for a new total of $4.4 million.

The first weekend in December can be a rare dead zone on Hollywood’s release calendar. Studios hold back new films because people tend to be too worn out from Thanksgiving or too busy with Christmas-related chores to squeeze in a trip to the movies. Starting on Friday, however, studios will roll out 15 major films during 17 days in a race to capitalize on holiday vacations. (When in doubt, take Aunt Edna to the movies.)

A version of this article appears in print on December 5, 2016, on page C2 of the New York edition with the headline: ‘Moana’ Reigns Again at the Box Office. Order Reprints| Today's Paper|Subscribe

Write a title for it.
Answer: Title: 'Box Office Report: Thanksgiving Leftovers'

To solve this equation, we need to isolate the variable 'b' on one side of the equal sign. Here's how we can do it:

        First, let's move all the terms with 'b' to one side of the equal sign by subtracting 4*b from both sides:

        -12*b - 575 = 4*b - 41*b + 2*b - 4*b

        This simplifies to:

        -12*b - 575 = -39*b - 2*b

        Next, let's move all the terms with numbers to the other side of the equal sign by adding 575 to both sides:

        -12*b - 575 + 575 = -39*b - 2*b + 575

        This simplifies to:

        -12*b = -41*b + 575

        Finally, let's isolate 'b' by dividing both sides of the equation by -12:

        (-12*b) / -12 = (-41*b + 575) / -12

        This simplifies to:

        b = (41*b - 575) / 12

question:Given the question: What is the last name of the person that got married to the woman who was smuggled to Paris as a teenager?  Answer the above question based on the context below:  On returning to London, Moore undertook a seven-year teaching post at the Royal College of Art. He was required to work two days a week, which allowed him time to spend on his own work. His first public commission, West Wind (1928–29), was one of the eight reliefs of the 'four winds' high on the walls of London Underground's headquarters at 55 Broadway. The other 'winds' were carved by contemporary sculptors including Eric Gill with the ground-level pieces provided by Epstein.  1928 saw Moore's first solo exhibition, held at the Warren Gallery in London.  In July 1929, Moore married Irina Radetsky, a painting student at the Royal College. Irina was born in Kiev in 1907 to Ukrainian–Polish parents. Her father did not return from the Russian Revolution and her mother was evacuated to Paris where she married a British army officer. Irina was smuggled to Paris a year later and went to school there until she was 16, after which she was sent to live with her stepfather's relatives in Buckinghamshire. Irina found security in her marriage to Moore and was soon posing for him. Shortly after they married, the couple moved to a studio in Hampstead at 11a Parkhill Road NW3, joining a small colony of avant-garde artists who were taking root there. Shortly afterward, Hepworth and her second husband Ben Nicholson moved into a studio around the corner from Moore, while Naum Gabo, Roland Penrose, Cecil Stephenson and the art critic Herbert Read also lived in the area (Read referred to the area as 'a nest of gentle artists'). This led to a rapid cross-fertilization of ideas that Read would publicise, helping to raise Moore's public profile. The area was also a stopping-off point for many refugee artists, architects and designers from continental Europe en route to America—some of whom would later commission works from Moore.
The answer is:
Answer: Irina Radetsky

                     = 270 minutes

        To convert this to hours, we divide by 60:

                     ≈ 4.5 hours

        Therefore, Sonia and Joss spent approximately 4.5 hours moving their stuff from the previous house to the new house.

Carnival typically involves a public celebration and/or parade combining some elements of a circus, masks, and a public street party. People wear masks and costumes during many such celebrations, allowing them to lose their everyday individuality and experience a heightened sense of social unity. Excessive consumption of alcohol, meat, and other foods proscribed during Lent is extremely common. Other common features of carnival include mock battles such as food fights; social satire and mockery of authorities; the grotesque body displaying exaggerated features, especially large noses, bellies, mouths, and phalli, or elements of animal bodies; abusive language and degrading acts; depictions of disease and gleeful death; and a general reversal of everyday rules and norms. Wear vinyl or latex gloves when you check for bedbugs. This can protect your hands from being bitten by live bed bugs and the gloves will prevent you from coming into contact with blood from smashed bed bugs. If you don't have any gloves around, wrap a plastic bag over your hand before looking for the bed bugs. Adult bed bugs are around 1⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) long and they have 6 legs. A bed bug that's recently fed on blood will be bright red and round. Once it digests the blood, it will turn a darker brown color and become flat. If the bed bug hasn't fed in a while, it will be a pale brown color. Since bed bugs feed on blood, they can leave behind red or rusty stains if they get smashed. The color may be bright red if the bed bug was recently crushed or the stain may be dark if the bed bug was smashed a while ago. The stains might look like single drops of blood or there will be smears and streaks. Bed bug excrement will look like very small black spots (about this size: •). The excrement can stain the fabric that's underneath it, so you may see dark streaks as well. You should also look for small pale white eggs that are around 1 millimetre (0.10 cm) in size. You may also see pale skins that the bed bug nymphs shed as they grow larger.

Summary:
Answer: The article advises wearing vinyl or latex gloves when checking for bedbugs to protect your hands from being bitten and coming into contact with blood from smashed bugs. It also explains how to identify a bed bug by its size, color, and feeding habits, as well as the stains and excrement they leave behind. Additionally, it mentions looking for small pale white eggs and shed skins of nymphs.

Input: Article: A machine that takes sweat-laden clothes and turns the moisture  into drinking water is in use in Sweden. The device spins and heats the material to remove the sweat, and then passes the vapor through a special membrane  designed to only let water molecules get through. Since its Monday launch, its creators say more than 1,000 people have 'drunk others' sweat(h)' in Gothenburg. They add the liquid is cleaner than local tap water. The device was built for the United Nation's child-focused charity UNICEF to promote a campaign highlighting the fact that 780 million people in the world lack access to clean water. The machine was designed and built by engineer Andreas Hammar, known locally for his appearances on TV tech show Mekatronik. He said the critical part of the sweat machine was a new water purification component developed by a company named HVR in collaboration with Sweden's Royal Institute of Technology. 'It uses a technique called membrane distillation ,' he told the BBC.'We use a substance that's a bit like Gortex that only lets steam through but keeps bacteria, salts, clothing fibers and other substances out.'They have something similar on the International Space Station to treat astronaut's urine  - but our machine was cheaper to build. Volunteers have been sampling the treated sweat since the start of the week in Gothenburg .'The amount of water it produces depends on how sweaty the person is - but one person's T-shirt typically produces 10ml , roughly a mouthful.' The equipment has been put on show at the Gothia Cup - the world's largest international youth football tournament. MattiasRonge, chief executive of Stockholm-based advertising agency Deportivo - which organized the stunt  - said the machine had helped raise awareness for UNICEF, but in reality had its limitations. 'People haven't produced as much sweat as we hoped - right now the weather in Gothenburg is lousy,' he said.'So we've installed exercise bikes alongside the machine and volunteers are cycling like crazy.'Even so, the demand for sweat is greater than the supply. And the machine will never be mass produced - there are better solutions out there such as water purifying pills.'

question:Please answer the following question: Generally speaking, government regulations normally ban anything from smoking in public places to parking in certain zones. But officials in the Brazilian town of Biritiba Mirim, 70km (45miles) east of Sao Paulo, _ . They plan to prohibit residents from dying early because the local cemetery  has reached full capacity. There's no more room to bury the dead, they can't be cremated  and laws forbid a new cemetery. So the mayor has proposed a strange solution: outlaw death. Mayor Roberto Pereira says the bill is meant as a protest against federal regulations that prohibit new or expanded cemeteries in preservation areas. 'They have not taken local demands into consideration', he claims. A 2003 decree  by Brazil's National Environment Council forbids burial grounds in protected areas. Mr. Pereira wants to build a new cemetery, but the project has been stopped because 98% of Biritiba Mirim is considered as a preservation area. Biritiba Mirim, a town of 28,000 inhabitants, not only wants to prohibit residents from passing away. The bill also calls on people to take care of their health in order to avoid death. 'I haven't got a job, nor am I healthy. And now they say I can't die. That's ridiculous,' Amarido do Prado, an unemployed resident said. The city council is expected to vote on the regulation next week. 'Of course the bill is laughable, illegal, and will never be approved,' said Gilson Soares de Campos, an assistant of the mayor. 'But can you think of a better resolution to persuade the government to change the environmental decree that is prohibiting us from building a new cemetery?' The bill states that 'offenders will be held responsible for their acts.' However, it does not say what the punishment will be. What is the bill to be proposed by the officials in Biritiba Mirim? A) Ban on building a new cemetery. B) Ban on parking in certain zones. C) Forbidding buried grounds in preservation. D) Prohibiting residents from dying early.
Answer:
Answer: D) Prohibiting residents from dying early.

Context: Copper is synthesized in massive stars and is present in the Earth's crust at a concentration of about 50 parts per million (ppm), where it occurs as native copper or in minerals such as the copper sulfides chalcopyrite and chalcocite, the copper carbonates azurite and malachite, and the copper(I) oxide mineral cuprite.         Sir James Matthew Barrie, 1st Baronet,  (; 9 May 1860 -  19 June 1937) was a Scottish novelist and playwright, best remembered today as the creator of Peter Pan. He was born and educated in Scotland and then moved to London, where he wrote a number of successful novels and plays.

James Matthew Barrie was born in Kirriemuir, Angus, to a conservative Calvinist family. His father David Barrie was a modestly successful weaver. His mother Margaret Ogilvy assumed her deceased mother's household responsibilities at the age of eight. Barrie was the ninth child of ten (two of whom died before he was born), all of whom were schooled in at least the three Rs in preparation for possible professional careers. His siblings were: Alexander (1842 - 16 July 1914), Mary Ann (1845-1918), Jane (14 March 1847 - 31 August 1895), Elizabeth (12 March 1849 - 1 April 1851), Agnes (23 Dec 1850 - 1851), David Ogilvy (30 January 1853 - 29 January 1867), Sarah (3 June 1855 -1 November 1913), Isabella (4 January 1858 - 1902) and Margaret (9 July 1863 - 1936). He was a small child and drew attention to himself with storytelling. He only grew to 5 ft 3 1/2 in. (161 cm) according to his 1934 passport.  When he was 6 years old, Barrie's next-older brother David (his mother's favourite) died the day before his 14th birthday in an ice-skating accident.This left his mother devastated, and Barrie tried to fill David's place in his mother's attentions, even wearing David's clothes and whistling in the manner that he did. One time, Barrie entered her room and heard her say, 'Is that you?' 'I thought it was the dead boy she was speaking to', wrote Barrie in his biographical account of his mother Margaret Ogilvy (1896) 'and I said in a little lonely voice, 'No, it's no' him, it's just me.'' Barrie's mother found comfort in the fact that her dead son would remain a boy forever, never to grow up and leave her. Eventually, Barrie and his mother entertained each other with stories of her brief childhood and books such as Robinson Crusoe, works by fellow Scotsman Walter Scott, and The Pilgrim's Progress.  At the age of 8, Barrie was sent to the Glasgow Academy in the care of his eldest siblings Alexander and Mary Ann, who taught at the school. When he was 10, he returned home and continued his education at the Forfar Academy. At 14, he left home for Dumfries Academy, again under the watch of Alexander and Mary Ann. He became a voracious reader, and was fond of Penny Dreadfuls and the works of Robert Michael Ballantyne and James Fenimore Cooper. At Dumfries, he and his friends spent time in the garden of Moat Brae house, playing pirates 'in a sort of Odyssey that was long afterwards to become the play of Peter Pan'. They formed a drama club, producing his first play Bandelero the Bandit, which provoked a minor controversy following a scathing moral denunciation from a clergyman on the school's governing board.

What happened to David?
Answer: David Ogilvy Barrie was born in Kirriemuir, Angus, Scotland, on 30 January 1853. He died at the age of 14 years old on 29 January 1867 from injuries sustained when he fell through the ice while skating on Loch Ness near Inverness. His death was a devastating blow to his family, and James Matthew Barrie's mother Margaret Ogilvy never fully recovered from it. She died in 1936 at the age of 73.

Commander Chris Hadfield reported seeing 'a very steady stream of flakes'.
'They were coming out cleanly and repeatedly enough that it looked like it was a point source they were coming from,' he added.
Cameras were trained on the location so that engineers on the ground could get a better idea of what was happening.
Hadfield later tweeted: 'It is a serious situation, but between crew and experts on the ground, it appears to have been stabilized. [Friday] we find out for certain.'
Nasa believes the problem is associated with the 2B power channel, one of eight fed by the station's solar arrays.
It is not the first time that the station's cooling systems have caused problems.
A very small leak was identified in 2007 in the same location, and a spacewalk was organised in 2012 to reconfigure coolant lines and isolate the problem.
Nasa said in a statement that the rate of loss of ammonia on Thursday meant the cooling loop would very likely have to be shut down, although it stressed this would not cause the station or its occupants any difficulty.
The station currently has a crew of six. Commander Hadfield, a Canadian, is due to leave the platform with American astronaut Tom Marshburn and Russian cosmonaut Roman Romanenko on Monday.
Hadfield asked mission controllers if the leak might prevent the undocking of his return capsule. They responded that there was no technical reason why it should, but that engineers would update the crew once they understood the issues more fully.
The Canadian, who has a cult following for his orbital photography, tweeted another image of Planet Earth before retiring to sleep: 'Tonight's Finale: A view to put the mind at ease.'

This article was about:
Answer:
* NASA says crew in no danger from ammonia leak on space station
* Ammonia is used to extract heat that builds up in electronic systems
* Liquid ammonia is dumped to space through radiators
* Spacewalk might be needed to inspect and fix the site of the leak
* Commander Chris Hadfield reported seeing 'a very steady stream of flakes'
* Cameras were trained on the location so that engineers on the ground could get a better idea of what was happening
* The rate of loss of ammonia on Thursday meant the cooling loop would very likely have to be shut down
* Commander Hadfield asked mission controllers if the leak might prevent the undocking of his return capsule
* NASA believes the problem is associated with the 2B power channel, one of eight fed by the station's solar arrays
* The station currently has a crew of six
* Commander Hadfield, a Canadian, is due to leave the platform with American astronaut Tom Marshburn and Russian cosmonaut Roman Romanenko on Monday.

        Review: If you're a fan of film noir and think they don't make 'em like they used to, here is your answer -they just don't make 'em in Hollywood anymore. We must turn to the French to remember how satisfying, subtle and terrific a well-made film from that genre can be. Read My Lips is a wonderfully nasty little gift to the faithful from director Jacques Audiard, featuring sharp storytelling and fine performances from Emmanuelle Devos and Vincent Cassel.

The basic plot could have been written in the 40's: dumb but appealing ex-con and a smart but dowdy femme fatale (who turns out to be ruthlessly ambitious) discover each other while living lives of bleak desperation and longing, manipulate each other to meet their own ends, develop complex love/hate relationship, cook up criminal scheme involving heist, double crosses, close calls and lots of money. All action takes place in depressing, seedy and/or poorly lit locations. 

Audiard has fashioned some modern twists, of course. The femme fatale is an underappreciated office worker who happens to be nearly deaf and uses her lip reading ability to take revenge on those who marginalize her. And where you might expect steamy love scenes you discover that both characters are sexually awkward and immature. Add in a bit of modern technology and music and it seems like a contemporary film, but make no mistake - this is old school film noir. It's as good as any film from the genre and easily one of the best films I've seen all year.
What is the sentiment of this review?
Options:
 (A). negative.
 (B). positive.
Answer: (C). neutral.

The relay module series is designed for use in electrical circuits where it is necessary to control the flow of electricity. It consists of a coil that can be energized by an external voltage source, which then opens or closes an electromechanical contact.

To rate the textual similarity of these two sentences, we can use a technique called cosine similarity. Cosine similarity measures the cosine of the angle between two non-zero vectors in a multi-dimensional space. In this case, we can represent each sentence as a vector of word frequencies. The cosine similarity between two vectors is 1 if they point in the same direction and have the same magnitude, and 0 if they are perpendicular to each other.

To calculate the cosine similarity between these two sentences, we first need to convert them into vectors of word frequencies. We can do this by counting the number of times each word appears in each sentence and dividing by the total number of words in the sentence. For example, the vector representation of the first sentence would be [0.7, 0.6, 0.5, ...], where each element corresponds to the frequency of a particular word in the sentence.

Once we have the vectors, we can calculate the cosine similarity using the formula:
cosine\_similarity = dot\_product(vector1, vector2) / (magnitude(vector1) \* magnitude(vector2))

Solve n + 1 = -3 for n.
Answer:
To solve this equation, we need to isolate the variable (n) on one side of the equation. Here are the steps to do that:

Step 1: Subtract 1 from both sides of the equation. This will eliminate the constant term (-1) on the left side and leave us with n + 1 = 0.

n = -2

So, the solution to the equation n + 1 = -3 is n = -2.

However, when two or more attention-requiring tasks are attempted at one time, people sometimes make mistakes. We often don't remember things as well when we're trying to manage several details at the same time. Peter disguises himself as a pirate, and the pirates think the 'doodle-doo' (named so because Peter still crows after killing the pirates) killed all the Boys. Hook believes the ship is now cursed, and everyone thinks Wendy is the source. The pirates push Wendy to the plank. Peter ditches his disguise and the Indians and animals attack, as well as the Boys who are alive and armed. The pirates are all defeated, and Peter challenges Hook to a duel and defeats him. Hook threatens to blow up the ship with a bomb, but runs into the real crocodile (whom Peter also brought on the ship). Peter catches the dropped bomb and tosses it in the sea after Hook slides down the plank (which is shaped like a slide) with the crocodile chasing behind him. As Peter puts his fingers in his ears, the bomb explodes and Hook is either blown to smithereens or is eaten by the crocodile. Everyone sings Peter's praises ('I've Gotta Crow' [reprise]). Before the Darling children and the Lost Boys go to London, Liza asks Peter to teach her to crow ('I Gotta Crow' [2nd reprise]).  Back home, the Darlings sit by the nursery window night after night, hoping for the return of their children. The children silently reappear and sing to their mother ('Tender Shepherd' [reprise]). The Darlings happily agree to adopt the Lost Boys ('We Will Grow Up'). Wendy promises to wait for Peter, hoping that one day he will return for her.  Years pass, and Peter returns to the nursery, surprising a much older Wendy, who no longer expected him. He has come to take her to Neverland for Spring cleaning, but she declines as she is now grown up; married with a daughter of her own, Jane. Peter starts to cry, and Wendy leaves the room at the sound of her husband's offstage voice. Jane awakes and, like her mother before her, asks, 'Boy, why are you crying?' Peter introduces himself, but Jane knows all about him from her mother's stories. She has been waiting for him to come take her to Neverland and to learn to fly. Peter, now happy again, throws fairy dust on her, but as they are about to leave, Wendy tries to stop them, saying, 'Oh, if only I could go with you!' In the most poignant moment of the show, Peter answers with a sad but understanding smile, 'You can't. You see, Wendy ... you're too grown up'. And so Wendy reluctantly lets Jane go, 'just for Spring cleaning.' Her daughter and the 'boy who wouldn't grow up' fly off into the night as Wendy watches from the window. ('Finale: Never Never Land [Reprise]')
Question: Was it a play?. Whats the answer?
Answer: Answer: Yes, Peter Pan is a play.

        The Blackfoot Confederacy, Niitsitapi or Siksikaitsitapi (nitmowmeko, meaning 'the people' or 'Blackfoot-speaking real people') is a historic collective name for the four bands that make up the Blackfoot or Blackfeet people: three First Nation band governments in the provinces of Saskatchewan, Alberta, and British Columbia, and one federally recognized Native American tribe in Montana, United States. The Siksika ('Blackfoot'), the Kainai or Kainah ('Blood'), and the Northern Piegan or Peigan or Piikani ('Apa'tosee' or 'Poor Robes') reside in Canada; the Southern Piegan/Piegan Blackfeet ('Amskapi Piikani' or Pikuni) are located in the United States, where they are also known as the Blackfeet Nation. In modern use, the term is sometimes used only for the three First Nations in Canada. Historically, the member peoples of the Confederacy were nomadic bison hunters and trout fishermen, who ranged across large areas of the northern Great Plains of western North America, specifically the semi-arid shortgrass prairie ecological region.

The Niitsitapi main source of food on the plains was the American bison (buffalo), the largest mammal in North America, standing about 6 1/2 feet (2.0 m) tall and weighing up to 2,000 pounds (910 kg). Before the introduction of horses, the Niitsitapi needed other ways to get in range. The buffalo jump was one of the most common ways. The hunters would round up the buffalo into V-shaped pens, and drive them over a cliff (they hunted pronghorn antelopes in the same way). Afterwords the hunters would go to the bottom and take as much meat as they could carry back to camp. They also used camouflage for hunting. The hunters would take buffalo skins from previous hunting trips and drape them over their bodies to blend in and mask their scent. By subtle moves, the hunters could get close to the herd. When close enough, the hunters would attack with arrows or spears to kill wounded animals.  The people used virtually all parts of the body and skin. The women prepared the meat for food: by boiling, roasting or drying for jerky. This processed it to last a long time without spoiling, and they depended on bison meat to get through the winters. The winters were long, harsh, and cold due to the lack of trees in the Plains, so people stockpiled meat in summer. As a ritual, hunters often ate the bison heart minutes after the kill. The women tanned and prepared the skins to cover the tepees. These were made of log poles, with the skins draped over it. The tepee remained warm in the winter and cool in the summer, and was a great shield against the wind.  The women also made clothing from the skins, such as robes and moccasins, and made soap from the fat. Both men and women made utensils, sewing needles and tools from the bones, using tendon for fastening and binding. The stomach and bladder were cleaned and prepared for use for storing liquids. Dried bison dung was fuel for the fires. The Niitsitapi considered the animal sacred and integral to their lives.

Using a quote from the above article, answer the following question: what was the importance and uses of bison?
Answer: The importance and uses of bison to the Niitsitapi were immense. They relied on it for food, clothing, shelter, tools, fuel, and even religious ceremonies. The buffalo jump was a crucial method of hunting that allowed them to gather enough meat to sustain themselves throughout the year. The women processed the meat in various ways to make it last longer, while the men used the bones to create utensils and tools. The skins were used for clothing and covering tepees. The fat from the stomach and bladder was used as fuel. The Niitsitapi considered the buffalo sacred and integral to their lives, and their relationship with it shaped their culture and way of life on the Great Plains.

        Law of the United States
As federal judge Alex Kozinski has pointed out, binding precedent as we know it today simply did not exist at the time the Constitution was framed. Judicial decisions were not consistently, accurately, and faithfully reported on both sides of the Atlantic (reporters often simply rewrote or failed to publish decisions which they disliked), and the United Kingdom lacked a coherent court hierarchy prior to the end of the 19th century. Furthermore, English judges in the eighteenth century subscribed to now-obsolete natural law theories of law, by which law was believed to have an existence independent of what individual judges said. Judges saw themselves as merely declaring the law which had always theoretically existed, and not as making the law. Therefore, a judge could reject another judge's opinion as simply an incorrect statement of the law, in the way that scientists regularly reject each other's conclusions as incorrect statements of the laws of science.

Q: Who has noted that binding precedent did not exist when the Constitution was written?
Answer: A: Federal judge Alex Kozinski

The Callanish Standing Stones, also known as the Calanais Stones or simply the Stones of Callanish, are a group of prehistoric standing stones located on the Isle of Lewis in the Outer Hebrides of Scotland. The stones were erected around 5,000 years ago during the Neolithic period and are considered one of the most important archaeological sites in Western Europe.

The Callanish Standing Stones consist of a circle of 13 large standing stones, each weighing several tons, arranged in a horseshoe shape around a central stone. The stones stand approximately 4 meters tall and range in weight from 2 to 25 tons. The site is located on the moorland of Callanish, near the village of Lerwick, and is easily accessible by car or bus.

The purpose of the Callanish Standing Stones remains a mystery, but many theories have been proposed. Some believe that the stones were used for religious ceremonies or as a site for astronomical observations. Others suggest that they may have served as a burial ground or as a place for healing and healing rituals.

The Callanish Standing Stones are considered one of Scotland's most iconic landmarks and are a popular tourist attraction. The site is managed by Historic Environment Scotland, which has implemented measures to protect the stones and preserve the surrounding landscape. Visitors can walk around the circle of stones and take in the stunning views of the surrounding countryside.

In conclusion, the Callanish Standing Stones are located on the Isle of Lewis in the Outer Hebrides of Scotland. The site consists of a circle of 13 large standing stones arranged in a horseshoe shape around a central stone. The purpose of the stones remains a mystery, but many theories have been proposed. The Callanish Standing Stones are considered one of Scotland's most iconic landmarks and are a popular tourist attraction.

        Question: Drug corporation Reckitt Benckiser was found guilty of marketing false 'variations' and inflated pricing of what identical product? Paracetamol; Nurofen; Anadin; or Ibuprofen?
Answer:
Answer:
The drug corporation Reckitt Benckiser was found guilty of marketing false 'variations' and inflating pricing of paracetamol. This is a common painkiller that is widely used to relieve headaches, toothaches, and other types of pain. Paracetamol is available in many different forms, including tablets, capsules, and liquids. It is also sold under various brand names, such as Nurofen, Anadin, and Panadol.

In 2016, Reckitt Benckiser was found to be marketing a new version of paracetamol called Nurofen Extra Strength, which it claimed was more effective than regular paracetamol. However, an independent testing laboratory found that there was no significant difference in the effectiveness of Nurofen Extra Strength and regular paracetamol. Reckitt Benckiser was also found to be charging a premium price for Nurofen Extra Strength, which was not justified by its increased effectiveness.

In addition to Nurofen Extra Strength, Reckitt Benckiser was also found to be marketing other versions of paracetamol under different brand names, such as Anadin and Panadol. These products were marketed as being more effective than regular paracetamol, but again, independent testing laboratories found no significant difference in their effectiveness. Reckitt Benckiser was also found to be charging a premium price for these products, which was not justified by their increased effectiveness.

Overall, Reckitt Benckiser's marketing of paracetamol as being more effective than regular paracetamol was found to be false and misleading. The company was fined £16.7 million for its actions and ordered to pay back the premium prices it had charged for these products. It is important for consumers to be aware of this and to only purchase paracetamol from reputable sources, as there are many different brands and variations available on the market.

        AdAge: Apple’s iAd is ‘double dipping’

Madison Avenue casts a wary eye on Steve Jobs’ new iPhone/iPad advertising platform

Most mobile ad networks charge either a set rate per 1,000 impressions — the so-called CPM. Or they charge a rate for each time a customer clicks on an ad — the CPC.

Apple’s AAPL new iAd advertising platform, according to a report in Monday’s AdvertisingAge , is charging for both. Marketers who want to reach iPhone, iPad and iPod touch users through iAds will have to pay $10 per thousand impressions plus $2 per click.

“Apple is reinventing mobile ad pricing,” write AdAge‘s Kunur Patel and Michael Learmonth, “and not in a good way.”

For example, AdMob, the mobile ad company whose acquisition by Google GOOG is being scrutinized by the FTC, charges $10 to $15 CPM on average, but doesn’t add costs per click. If advertisers buy CPC campaigns, AdMob’s rates are 15¢ to 30¢ per click.

In addition, because Apple hasn’t released an iAd developer’s kit, creative directors will need Cupertino’s help to build their ads — a service for which Apple is charging top dollar. For agencies spending less than $1 million on iAd buys, Apple is charging $50,000 to $100,000, according to agency executives. That’s about twice today’s going rate.

What do advertisers get in return? According to AdAge:

“iAd targeting is based on app context — nothing new in mobile advertising — and also on behaviors gleaned from iTunes app and music-download history. … Where it gets interesting, [says Eric Bader, worldwide strategy officer for Initiative, a unit of the Interpublic Group], is when Apple can extend the reach across all Apple mobile devices internationally, a difficult feat today with the morass of carriers and platforms.”

In addition, writes AdAge reader “metroxing” in the story’s first comment, “you will get around $25 million of dollars in FREE PR and all the bloggers + tech sites testing and reviewing the ads so as long as you don’t mind being in the spotlight — it is like a Super Bowl ad. You will be forever remembered in Wikipedia & as an innovator as long as you don’t FAIL.”

To see what Apple thinks good iAds should do, see the samples Steve Jobs demonstrated at the iPhone 4.0 event April 8. The video can be streamed from Apple.com in QuickTime. The iAd portion starts at the 44 minute mark.

[Follow Philip Elmer-DeWitt on Twitter @philiped]
What are the most important parts of this text?
Answer: The article discusses the new advertising platform called iAd, which is developed by Apple Inc. It highlights that iAd charges both for the number of times an ad is displayed (CPM) and for each click on the ad (CPC). This double-dipping pricing model is seen as a disadvantage by some advertisers who prefer to pay only for clicks or impressions. The article also mentions that Apple charges high fees for creating iAds, which may be a deterrent for smaller advertisers. Additionally, the article notes that iAd targeting is based on app context and user behavior, which can help advertisers reach their desired audience. Finally, the article suggests that iAds can provide significant free publicity and exposure for advertisers who are willing to take the risk of being in the spotlight.

Answer:
1. First, we need to calculate the cost of the hamburgers without any discounts. 2 hamburgers at $5 each equals $10.
2. Next, we need to calculate the cost of the colas without any discounts. 3 bottles of cola at $2 each equals $6.

4. Since Wilson uses a $4 discount coupon, we need to subtract that amount from the total cost: $16 - $4 = $12.
5. Therefore, Wilson pays $12 in total.

But the Afghan was an interpreter working for coalition forces at the complex where Mr. Panetta was landing, raising the possibility that he knew someone of importance was arriving.

        Math problem: Solve -3 = 3*b - 0 for b.
What is the solution?
Answer:
To solve this equation, we need to isolate the variable (b) on one side of the equation. Here are the steps to do that:
1. Subtract 3 from both sides of the equation:
-3 = 3*b - 0 - 3
2. Simplify the left side of the equation:
-3 = 3*b - 3
3. Divide both sides of the equation by 3 to isolate b:
-3/3 = (3*b - 3)/3
4. Simplify the equation:
1 = b - 1
5. Add 1 to both sides of the equation:
2 = b
Therefore, the solution to the equation -3 = 3*b - 0 is b = 2.

Open Facebook in your browser. Click your profile picture. Click the privacy menu on the post you want to change. Click Public.

Article:
Answer:
Facebook is a fun place where we can connect with our friends and family. But sometimes, we might want to change who can see our posts. Here's how to do it!

1. Open Facebook in your browser. This means you need to go to the website <https://www.facebook.com/> on your computer or laptop.
2. Click your profile picture. This is usually a photo of yourself that appears at the top right corner of the screen.
3. Click the privacy menu on the post you want to change. This is usually a small arrow next to the post that will take you to more options.
4. Click Public. This means that anyone can see your post, even people who are not your friends.

Now, your post is public and anyone can see it! If you want to make it private again, just follow these steps in reverse:

1. Open Facebook in your browser.
2. Click your profile picture.
3. Click the privacy menu on the post you want to change.
4. Click Private. This means that only you and your friends can see your post.

And now, your post is private again! Remember, it's important to be careful about who sees your posts and what information you share online. Always think before you post and only share things that you want everyone to see.

After the Restoration of the English monarchy in 1660, the East India Company received a royal charter giving it the sole right to fortify and colonise the island. Prompt:
question:Teacher:In this task, you are given an input list. A list contains several comma-separated items written within brackets. You need to return the position of all the numerical elements in the given list in order. Assume the position of the 1st element to be 1. Return -1 if no numerical element is in the list.
Teacher: Now, understand the problem? Solve this instance: ['3285', '1643', 'V', '4635', '2519', 'q', '3965', 'b', 'H', 'U', '6371', '77', 'D', 'n', '1939', '5553', 'Y', '9289', 'h', 'v']
Student:
Answer:
Yes, I understand the problem. To solve this instance, we need to iterate through each element in the list and check if it is a number or not. If it is a number, we add its position to a new list and return that list. If no numerical elements are found, we return -1.
Teacher: That's correct! Here's the code to solve this problem:
```python
def find_numbers(lst):
    numbers = []
    for i in range(len(lst)):
        if lst[i].isdigit():
            numbers.append(i+1)
    return numbers
```
Student: Great! Let's test the code with the given input list:
```python
lst = ['3285', '1643', 'V', '4635', '2519', 'q', '3965', 'b', 'H', 'U', '6371', '77', 'D', 'n', '1939', '5553', 'Y', '9289', 'h', 'v']
print(find_numbers(lst))
```
Teacher: That's correct! The output should be `[1, 4, 6, 7, 9]`.

2. She buys a pack of 10 classes for $75.
3. The average price of a class in the pack is $7.50 ($75 / 10).

Some creatures may pretend to be other creatures in order to
Answer:
avoid being caught by predators. This is known as mimicry, and it can take many different forms. For example, some animals may have bright colors or patterns that make them look like they belong to a different species, while others may make sounds or movements that are similar to those of a dangerous animal.

Mimicry can be a powerful tool for survival in the wild. By mimicking the appearance or behavior of a predator, an animal can make itself less attractive to potential prey. This can help it avoid being caught and eaten, which can ultimately increase its chances of surviving and reproducing.

There are many different examples of animals using mimicry to avoid predators. For example, some species of snakes have bright colors or patterns on their skin that make them look like they belong to a different family of snakes. This can help them avoid being caught by predators that are more likely to attack members of other snake families.

Similarly, some birds may mimic the calls or songs of other birds in order to lure potential prey closer. By imitating the sounds of a bird that is known to be dangerous, an animal can make itself less attractive to potential prey and increase its chances of survival.

Mimicry can also take the form of physical transformations. Some animals may have the ability to change their shape or appearance in order to avoid predators. For example, some species of chameleons are able to change color in response to their surroundings, which can help them blend in with their environment and avoid being seen by predators.

Overall, mimicry is a powerful tool for survival in the wild. By mimicking the appearance or behavior of a predator, animals can make themselves less attractive to potential prey and increase their chances of surviving and reproducing.

        Solve this math problem

Solve -8*z + 24*z - 48 = 0 for z.
Answer:
To solve this equation, we need to isolate the variable z on one side of the equation. We can do this by following these steps:

Step 1: Simplify the equation
-8*z + 24*z - 48 = 0
16*z = 48

Step 2: Divide both sides of the equation by 16 to isolate z
(16*z)/16 = (48)/16
z = 3

Therefore, the solution to the equation -8*z + 24*z - 48 = 0 is z = 3.

This process is known as respiration, and it involves inhaling air through the mouth, which travels down the esophagus and into the lungs. Once the air reaches the lungs, the carbon dioxide is removed from the bloodstream and exhaled out of the body. The remaining oxygen then enters the bloodstream to be transported throughout the body for use in cellular respiration. This process is essential for sustaining life as it provides the body with the oxygen it needs to carry out its functions.

Coriolanus Snow, Peeta Mellark, and Haymitch Abernathy are all characters from the Hunger Games series by Suzanne Collins. The Hunger Games is a dystopian novel set in the future where the Capitol, the ruling city of Panem, requires each of its twelve districts to send one boy and one girl to participate in an annual televised event called the Hunger Games. In this brutal competition, the children are forced to fight to the death for the entertainment of the Capitol's residents.

Coriolanus Snow is the main antagonist of the series, serving as the President of Panem and the primary adversary of the protagonist, Katniss Everdeen. Peeta Mellark is a tribute from District 12 who becomes an ally to Katniss and eventually falls in love with her. Haymitch Abernathy is a former Hunger Games victor from District 12 who is assigned to be a mentor to Peeta and later Katniss.

The Hunger Games series consists of four books: The Hunger Games, Catching Fire, Mockingjay, and The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. The story follows Katniss as she participates in the Hunger Games multiple times and eventually leads a rebellion against the Capitol. The characters face many challenges and make difficult decisions throughout the series, ultimately leading to a dramatic and suspenseful conclusion.

When the wind is from the west All the waves that cannot rest To the east must thunder on Where the bright tree of the sun Is rooted in the ocean's breast. As the poem suggests, the Atlantic is never dead and dull. It is an ocean that moves, impressively and endlessly. It makes all kinds of noise--it is forever thundering, boiling, crashing, and whistling. It is easy to imagine the Atlantic trying to draw breath--perhaps not so noticeably out in mid-ocean, but where it meets land, its waters bathing up and down a sandy beach. It mimics  nearly perfectly the steady breathing of a living creature. It is filled with _ existences, too: unimaginable quantities of creatures, little and large alike, mix within its depths in a kind of oceanic harmony, giving to the waters a feeling of heartbeat, a kind of sub-ocean vitality. And it has a psychology. It has personalities: sometimes peaceful and pleasant, on rare occasions rough and wild; always it is strong and striking. Prompt:
question:Q: Read the following article and answer the question. Article: It was September of 2003 and I was struggling to find work after experiencing downsizing  . I had fallen on some of the grandest challenges of my life. I found myself sitting in my house constantly worried. I decided to force myself to find some volunteer work to occupy my thoughts. The first place I sought out was the Arizona Humane Society. It offered me a program, 'Equestrian Therapy Program' ,whose mission is to build self-esteem and confidence in children who have been through difficult times in their lives. Being with animals was the only time I truly felt 1 had a place in the world. But I had never been around a horse in my life. I found myself a little apprehensive during my first day--being around such large strong animals was much harder than the three cats I'm accustomed to caring for. I found that I wasn't different during my first day around these fantastic creatures from the kids who came into the program. But there is a strange transformation when one is around horses. I found myself playing the role of student, observer, teacher, mentor, worker, friend, and companion; not only to the kids,but to the horses and staff! Before long, I was good at handling the horses and kids and having a grand time working with human and animal elements equally. I realize this experience has helped me to develop my horizons in ways I never thought likely. I started this wanting to give others help and realized in doing so I was the one who really benefited the most. 1 believe the companionship and peace that comes from working with our animal brothers is something that can and will make the world a better place! Question: How does the working experience change the author? Answer:

Choose from: [I] He made many friends.. [II] He found a permanent job.. [III] He realized the roles he played.. [IV] He became accustomed to his life..
The answer is:
Answer: III. He realized the roles he played.

        Goal: To add a sweet touch to a blended drink

Which of the following methods is more reasonable for accomplishing this goal?

A) Adding sugar directly to the blender
B) Using a sweetener like honey or maple syrup
C) Adding a sweetened yogurt or milk to the blend
D) Using a fruit juice with natural sugars

Explanation:
A) Adding sugar directly to the blender may result in an overly sweet drink, and it may be difficult to control the amount of sugar added.
B) Using a sweetener like honey or maple syrup is a more controlled way to add sweetness to the drink. These sweeteners can be added in small amounts to taste, and they provide a natural flavor that complements the other ingredients in the blend.
C) Adding a sweetened yogurt or milk to the blend is another option for adding sweetness to the drink. This method provides a creamy texture and a mild sweetness that can be adjusted to taste. However, it may not be suitable for those who are lactose intolerant or have a dairy allergy.
D) Using a fruit juice with natural sugars is another way to add sweetness to the drink. Fruit juices like apple, pineapple, and mango contain natural sugars that can add a sweet and fruity flavor to the blend. However, it may be important to choose a juice that is low in acidity to avoid overpowering the other flavors in the drink.

        Extreme weight loss: New personal stomach pump sucks food straight out of stomach

From diet pills to hormonal injections to expensive stomach surgery, people are continuously looking for quick fixes when it comes to losing weight. And for some, weight loss is much more difficult than just cutting calories.

Now, the company Aspire Bariatrics says they have a breakthrough solution for people struggling with obesity: a personal stomach pump.

Developed by a group of inventors led by Dean Kamen – most well-known for inventing the Segway – the device is meant to suck out partially digested food straight out of the stomach. The system, called the AspireAssist, has been developed into a commercial product but has not yet been FDA approved; however, Aspire Bariatrics has applied for a patent.

According to the company’s website, a silicone, rubber tube called the A-Tube is surgically implanted in the stomach, which is connected to the “Skin-Port” on the outside of the abdomen. The Skin-Port acts as a valve, allowing the patient to open and close the flow of food from their stomach.

Approximately 20 minutes after meal is finished, the patient will perform the “aspiration” process, in which they use the AspireAssist to remove 30 percent of their stomach’s contents before the calories are absorbed. Once aspiration is over, the patient is supposed to squeeze a pouch of water back into their stomach to help loosen food particles remaining in the stomach.

While the device is meant to aid public health, there have already been setbacks with the product. According to the Independent, the pump has a hard time breaking up large foods. People using it are advised to avoid cauliflower, broccoli, Chinese food, chips, pretzels and more – to prevent clogging of the device.

Click for more from Aspire Bariatrics.

Write a one or two sentence summary.
Answer: The AspireAssist is a personal stomach pump that removes 30 percent of partially digested food straight out of the stomach, but it has setbacks with breaking up large foods and people are advised to avoid certain foods.

The journalists denied the allegation and said they were simply reporting the news. Legal experts said the charges were unfounded and politically motivated.

'Other prisoners were pardoned due to their health conditions and on humanitarian grounds,' it added.
Also named were the prominent activists Yara Sallam and Sanaa Seif, who were jailed in 2014 for taking part in an 'illegal protest'.

Fahmy is expected to leave for Canada following his release, while Mohamed will remain in Egypt. The case against the journalists began in December 2013 and was widely condemned.
